channel.title: My first C++ attempt

item.title: My first C++ attempt
item.dc:creator: @Ecko Ecko
item.description:
@Ecko wrote:

[quote=“Taharok, post:17, topic:464056”][quote author=Ecko link=topic=567838.msg4127667#msg4127667 date=1350672182]

@Ecko: The game industry does primarily use C++ for game development. That’s not ignorant. Although there are some unusual studios that don’t (such as Jagex), and other studios that can’t (such as mobile studios, which are generally forced into using objective c or java, though not so much anymore). The major studios will generally prefer C++ as the main language of choice because of its speed and ability to perform under stress. A lot comes down to the programmer using it, of course. But it can be very challenging to achieve the same performance in most other general purpose languages that you can in C++, unless those languages are also directly compiled to arch-dependent machine code (plus you have to consider the evolution of modern C++ compilers and their ability to generate very good assembly to represent your high-level code).

My comment was more directed to the statement saying you never hear of game companies using other languages. A lot of classic games were written in C, in particular those using id Tech 3 as the game engine.

Minecraft was programmed in Java as well.
[/quote]

Lol, I never said that. Your statement was clearly misdirected.[/quote]
I know you didn’t say it, Lin did. I was paraphrasing what he said…

Read full topic

[/quote]
My comment was more directed to the statement saying you never hear of game companies using other languages. A lot of classic games were written in C, in particular those using id Tech 3 as the game engine.

item.title: My first C++ attempt
item.dc:creator: @Ecko Ecko
item.description:
@Ecko wrote:

Taharok:

@Ecko: The game industry does primarily use C++ for game development. That’s not ignorant. Although there are some unusual studios that don’t (such as Jagex), and other studios that can’t (such as mobile studios, which are generally forced into using objective c or java, though not so much anymore). The major studios will generally prefer C++ as the main language of choice because of its speed and ability to perform under stress. A lot comes down to the programmer using it, of course. But it can be very challenging to achieve the same performance in most other general purpose languages that you can in C++, unless those languages are also directly compiled to arch-dependent machine code (plus you have to consider the evolution of modern C++ compilers and their ability to generate very good assembly to represent your high-level code).

My comment was more directed to the statement saying you never hear of game companies using other languages. A lot of classic games were written in C, in particular those using id Tech 3 as the game engine.

Minecraft was programmed in Java as well.

item.title: My first C++ attempt
item.dc:creator: @mod_taharok Taharok
item.description:
@mod_taharok wrote:

[quote=“iKilem, post:9, topic:464056”][quote author=Taharok link=topic=567838.msg4124627#msg4124627 date=1350235657]
You can also optimize the conditionals by checking for multiples of 15 first, then for multiples of 3, then for multiples of 5, rather than doing two remainder calculations for each conditional. You can basically halve the number of modulus checks this way.
[/quote]
That’s what I meant, unless you were following up from a different post when you said “also”.[/quote]

I’m not sure now. It was a follow-up to yours, I suppose.

@The Enforcer: I was talking about relative to the original code. He was doing upwards of 6 modulus checks for each iteration, whereas I pointed out his approach to solving it could be simplified and optimized by using less moduluses. And thanks for pointing out the shader languages are general purpose. I figure that was obvious. It’s worth mentioning them though, considering there’s also CG and various general purpose languages that are translated into shader languages to work around design flaws in those languages.

@Ecko: The game industry does primarily use C++ for game development. That’s not ignorant. Although there are some unusual studios that don’t (such as Jagex), and other studios that can’t (such as mobile studios, which are generally forced into using objective c or java, though not so much anymore). The major studios will generally prefer C++ as the main language of choice because of its speed and ability to perform under stress. A lot comes down to the programmer using it, of course. But it can be very challenging to achieve the same performance in most other general purpose languages that you can in C++, unless those languages are also directly compiled to arch-dependent machine code (plus you have to consider the evolution of modern C++ compilers and their ability to generate very good assembly to represent your high-level code).

Read full topic

item.title: My first C++ attempt
item.dc:creator: @iKilem iKilem
item.description:
@iKilem wrote:

[quote=“The Enforcer, post:13, topic:464056”]Solving this problem using modulus operations is totally impractical in the first place. However, before you put an “optimization” into action you should analyze the resulting algorithm - it might not be an optimization after all. You’re afraid that two modulus operations on each iteration is too much, so you tried to optimize it with the following.

for (int i = 1; i <= 100; ++i)
{
	if (i % 15 == 0)
	{

	}
	else if (i % 3 == 0)
	{

	}
	else if (i % 5 == 0)
	{

	}
}

n = 100
mul15 = 100 / 15 = 6. modulus operations: 6 * 1 = 6.
mul3 = 100 / 3 - mul15 = 27. modulus operations: 27 * 2 = 54.
mul5 = 100 / 5 - mul15 = 14. modulus operations: 14 * 3 = 42.
other = 100 - mul15 - mul3 - mul5 = 53. modulus operations: 53 * 3 = 159.
total modulus operations: 6 + 54 + 42 + 159 = 261.
261 > 200.[/quote]
Two modulus operations on each iteration? It depends on the value of i. You are talking about the original code, right?

Read full topic

item.title: My first C++ attempt
item.dc:creator: @The_Enforcer The Enforcer
item.description:
@The_Enforcer wrote:

Taharok:

You can also optimize the conditionals by checking for multiples of 15 first, then for multiples of 3, then for multiples of 5, rather than doing two remainder calculations for each conditional. You can basically halve the number of modulus checks this way.

Solving this problem using modulus operations is totally impractical in the first place. However, before you put an “optimization” into action you should analyze the resulting algorithm - it might not be an optimization after all. You’re afraid that two modulus operations on each iteration is too much, so you tried to optimize it with the following.

for (int i = 1; i <= 100; ++i)
{
	if (i % 15 == 0)
	{

	}
	else if (i % 3 == 0)
	{

	}
	else if (i % 5 == 0)
	{

	}
}

n = 100
mul15 = 100 / 15 = 6. modulus operations: 6 * 1 = 6.
mul3 = 100 / 3 - mul15 = 27. modulus operations: 27 * 2 = 54.
mul5 = 100 / 5 - mul15 = 14. modulus operations: 14 * 3 = 42.
other = 100 - mul15 - mul3 - mul5 = 53. modulus operations: 53 * 3 = 159.
total modulus operations: 6 + 54 + 42 + 159 = 261.
261 > 200.

[quote=“Ecko, post:12, topic:464056”][quote author=Lin link=topic=567838.msg4125110#msg4125110 date=1350279653]

Inb4 your friend starts lying to you about how ‘bad’ Java is.

What? My friend said that if I wanted to take game development seriously, I should learn C++.
[/quote]This is true. The college I’m most likely going to to major in game creation teaches C++ and C++ only. You never hear about major game companies using a language like C# or Java.

Lots of companies use C++ with other languages (including C#). Unreal Engine used C++ with GLSL, HLSL, C#. id Tech 3 was written completely in C and is the engine of many classic games. People still use the engine to create games since id released the source. The entire Call of Duty franchise was built on an engine written in C.

Saying C++ is the only language of major game companies is ignorant, especially considering the forum you’re saying it on (a RuneScape based forum).[/quote]

HLSL and GLSL are not general purpose programming languages. And it’s kind of obvious that you program your shaders with HLSL or GLSL whether you use Direct3D or OpenGL.

Read full topic

item.title: My first C++ attempt
item.dc:creator: @Ecko Ecko
item.description:
@Ecko wrote:

[quote=“Lin, post:10, topic:464056”][quote author=Ambokile link=topic=567838.msg4124667#msg4124667 date=1350239540]

Inb4 your friend starts lying to you about how ‘bad’ Java is.

What? My friend said that if I wanted to take game development seriously, I should learn C++.
[/quote]This is true. The college I’m most likely going to to major in game creation teaches C++ and C++ only. You never hear about major game companies using a language like C# or Java.[/quote]
Lots of companies use C++ with other languages (including C#). Unreal Engine used C++ with GLSL, HLSL, C#. id Tech 3 was written completely in C and is the engine of many classic games. People still use the engine to create games since id released the source. The entire Call of Duty franchise was built on an engine written in C.

Saying C++ is the only language of major game companies is ignorant, especially considering the forum you’re saying it on (a RuneScape based forum).

Read full topic

item.dc:creator: @iKilem iKilem
item.description:
@iKilem wrote:

The lowest common multiple of 3 and 5 is 15. Use that fact to write something with fewer conditionals.

item.title: My first C++ attempt
item.dc:creator: @whackatre Whackatre
item.description:
@whackatre wrote:

impl in ruby (same picture).

[code=ruby]
COUNT = 100

chart = {
3 => ‘Fizz’,
5 => ‘Buzz’,
7 => ‘Bazz’,
11 => ‘Mezz’,
13 => ‘Rozz’
}

(1…COUNT).each do |i|
found = false
for num in chart.keys.sort # to get the order correct.
found = true and print chart[num] if i % num == 0
end
print i if not found
puts ‘’
end[/code]

?

Read full topic

item.title: My first C++ attempt
item.dc:creator: @Fat_Cookies Fat Cookies
item.description:
@Fat_Cookies wrote:

Well you’ve produced the standard, boring and non-flexible solution that most people would come up with. If I told you also print out “Bazz” for multiple of 7’s your code would require a substantial amount of editing and turn into a mess.

Try and rewrite the program so that you can easily add new keywords for new multiples (such as Bazz). Think about how you could utilize an array to do this.

Read full topic

item.title: My first C++ attempt
item.dc:creator: @Ambokile Ambokile
item.description:
@Ambokile wrote:

My friend told me that I should try to learn C++ rather than Java so I thought I’d give it a go. He gave me a small task to complete.

My task:

Write a program that prints the numbers from 1 to 100. But for multiples of three print "Fizz" instead of the number and for the multiples of five print "Buzz". For numbers which are multiples of both three and five print "FizzBuzz".

My code:

[code=Cpp]#include

using namespace std;

int main() {
for (int i = 1; i <= 100; i++) {
if(i%3 == 0 && i%5 != 0) {
cout << “Fizz” << endl;
} else if(i%3 != 0 && i%5 == 0) {
cout << “Buzz” << endl;
} else if(i%3 == 0 && i%5 == 0) {
cout << “FizzBuzz” << endl;
} else {
cout << i << endl;
}
}
return 0;
}[/code]

I was wondering if anyone could tell me any points to improve.

Read full topic
